docs.lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service is teaching its auditors how to uncover tax cheating by self-styled business consultants and by corporations that use former employees as consultants to avoid withholding income, Social Security and Medicare taxes. A new audit technique guide, posted at the I.R.S. Web site, instructs auditors to check the business records of consultants to determine whether they are improperly deducting vacations and family travel on their tax return.

docs.lead_paragraph: IT is 7:45 p.m. on a steamy Friday in Manhattan, and the doors to the trailers that shelter the principal actresses of HBO's bed-hopping hit, ''Sex and the City,'' are snapping shut like mechanical jaws: time for the lunch break on the East 19th Street set. And quitting time for Cynthia Nixon, the veteran stage actress who plays Miranda Hobbes, the hardheaded, redheaded corporate lawyer lately dabbling in celibacy (daring behavior on this libido-baring show) after a slew of dud romances. In real life, which entails motherhood, grocery shopping and tidying a three-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side, the actress has ''studiously avoided creepy guys'' and has been hitched, in all but the legal sense, for the last 15 years to Danny Mozes, a noncreepy guy she has known since junior high. ''I'm not much of a flitter, not much of a flirter,'' she says. ''The chase doesn't interest me much.'' But on the show, which is in its fourth season and has her permission to run forever (try getting paid 10 times what you're used to and see if you want the bubble to burst), she is just as bewitched, bothered and bewildered as the next girl.

docs.lead_paragraph: Health care experts told a City Council committee yesterday that women in some parts of New York can expect a three-to-four-month wait for mammograms, critical tests in the early detection of breast cancer, and that the problem is likely to become worse. ''There is an imminent crisis that has been brewing for several years in providing these services,'' said Dr. Robert A. Schmidt, an associate professor of radiology at New York University Medical Center. ''We are beginning to see closures of mammography facilities and increased waiting times for screening and diagnostic appointments, both of which serve to restrict access.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: With the patients' bill of rights getting a new lease on life (front page, June 20), there is one item I would like to bring to lawmakers' attention: major medical insurance. I have been involved in the management of doctor billing for eight years and have found that insurance companies ignore the major medical portion of a policy when processing a claim. They deny services as not covered when in fact the major medical portion of the policy covers the item. Because patients may be unaware that they must file a separate claim to a different address, they often pay for the service, thus saving insurance companies millions of dollars.
